I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) to the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  in  2002,  the  Government  requested  ADB  technical 
assistance (TA) for preparing the Jiangsu Urban Environment Improvement Project.1 The ADB 
TA Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in February 2003. An understanding was reached with 
the Government on the scope, approach, and implementation and financing arrangements of 
the TA in July 2003. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC’s energy requirements for economic growth are to a large extent met from 
domestically produced coal. The PRC’s primary commercial energy supply consists of coal 
(68%), followed by oil (21%),  hydropower (8%), and natural gas (3%). Total installed power 
generation capacity was about 353 gigawatts (GW) at the end of 2002, and is estimated to 
reach 540 GW by 2010. The PRC’s power generation is predominantly coal-based (about 75%), 
followed by hydropower (about 24%), and by oil, natural gas, and nuclear power (about 1%). In 
2002 total coal production in the PRC was about 1.39 billion tons, which represented an 
increase of about 26% over that in 2001. Domestic coal consumption in 2002 was estimated at 
1.3 billion tons. 
 
3.  The PRC’s heavy dependence on coal as energy source has resulted in substantial 
environmental damage due to pollution from particulate matter (PM), sulfur dioxide (SO ), 
2
nitrogen oxides (NO ), and other harmful elements occurring in coal. SO  and NO  are the main 
x 2 x
precursor gases that cause acid rain, one of the largest environmental problems of the PRC and 
East Asia. Approximately 80% of SO  emissions in the PRC originate from coal combustion in 
2
the power and industry sectors and result in estimated annual damages of $14 billion.2 A recent 
report3 estimated that environmental costs of urban air pollution, indoor air pollution, and acid 
rain are 5%, 2%, and more than 1% of the gross domestic product, respectively. Carbon dioxide 
(CO ) is also a by-product of often inefficient coal combustion, while coal mining in the PRC is 
2
associated with the release of substantial quantities of methane (CH) into the atmosphere. Both 
4
CO  and CH are harmful greenhouse gases. The PRC is the second largest CO  producing 
2 4 2
country in the world and, if current trends continue, is expected to become the largest CO  
2
emitter by 2020. It is estimated that in 2002, about 6 billion cubic meters (m3) of CH, which was 
4
produced by coal mines in the PRC, was vented into the atmosphere. With the increasing depth 
of underground coal mining operations in the PRC, this volume is expected to increase in the 
future. The total CH reserves that could be produced from coal mines in the PRC up to a depth 
4
of 2,000 meters are estimated at 30–35 trillion m3. 
 
4.  It is acknowledged that environmental pollution associated with the use of coal in the 
PRC has disproportionately affected the poor. Poorer households usually rely on raw coal and 
biomass (for example wood and animal dung) for cooking and heating, and suffer accordingly 
from indoor air pollution. Also, coal is often used to produce town gas for distribution to urban 
households for cooking and heating; however, the production of town gas is associated with 
considerable pollution while town gas itself carries harmful substances and is relatively unsafe 
to use. The poor are the most vulnerable to diseases caused by environmental pollution and are 
the least financially capable to seek medical care.

5.  In its Tenth Five-Year Plan, 2001–2005, the Government assigned high priority to 
increasing the share of natural gas, which is a clean fuel, in the primary commercial energy 
supply mix. For this purpose it has begun developing major gas infrastructure projects, including 
a natural gas transmission pipeline from the Tarim Basin in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous 
Region with estimated gas reserves of about 8.4 trillion m3 to the Shanghai area (the west-east 
gas pipeline) and three receiving terminals and related facilities in the provinces of Guangdong, 
Fujian, and Jiangsu4 for the importation of liquefied natural gas (LNG). It is envisaged that the 
west-east gas pipeline will supply 12 billion m3 of natural gas a year to the eastern part of the 
PRC by 2010 while at the same time, the two LNG projects in the provinces of Guangdong and 
Fujian would be completed and would supply about 5.6 million tons of LNG a year, which, 
following gasification of the LNG, would be equivalent to about 7.6 billion m3 of natural gas a 
year. Initially, the main consumers of natural gas will be power plants. It is envisaged that over 
the next 3 years, about 10 gas-fired power plants with a total capacity of 8,600 megawatts (MW) 
will be constructed in the Shanghai area and near the locations of the LNG terminals. It is also 
envisaged that, at the same time along the west-east gas pipeline, additional gas-based power 
plants with a total capacity of up to 3,000 MW will be built in the provinces of Henan, Jiangsu, 
and Zhenjiang. It is further estimated that there are about 17 million households in Shanghai 
and the provinces of Jiangsu and Zhejiang alone, which would use natural gas; this number of 
households is expected to increase to 34 million in about 10 years. Natural gas from the East 
China  Sea  has  already  been  successfully  introduced  in  Shanghai  and  is  being  used  by 
commercial establishments and households throughout the city, with support from ADB.5 
 
6.  The west-east gas pipeline is about 4,200 kilometers (km) long. It will traverse the 
Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region and the provinces of Gansu, Ningxia, Shaanxi, Henan, 
Anhui, and Jiangsu and will end in the Shanghai area. The cost of the west-east gas pipeline is 
estimated at $5.6 billion. It is to be constructed by a consortium of international oil and gas 
companies  comprising  PetroChina  (PRC,  50%),  Sinopec  (PRC,  5%),  ExxonMobil  (United 
States,  15%),  Shell  (United  Kingdom,  15%),  and  Gazprom  (Russia,  15%).6  At  present, 
PetroChina has completed about 60% of the western section of the pipeline between the Tarim 
Basin in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region and the city of Jingbian in Shaanxi Province. It 
is expected that the eastern section of the pipeline from Shaanxi Province to the Shanghai area 
will be completed by early January 2004. Subsequently, some natural gas from fields in Shaanxi 
Province7 will be delivered in the Shanghai area, which will be followed by natural gas deliveries 
from the Tarim Basin by early 2005 when the entire pipeline will be completed. 
 
7.  Jiangsu is one of the PRC’s fastest growing provinces with the private sector as the 
major source of growth. The provincial government of Jiangsu is planning to use as much 
natural gas as possible from the west-east gas pipeline to reduce the use of coal, coal-based 
town gas, and petroleum products (including liquefied petroleum gas [LPG]). At present, about 
80% of the commercial primary energy demand of Jiangsu is met by coal, with the remaining 
20% being met by hydropower, petroleum products, and nuclear power. The total installed 
power generation capacity in Jiangsu is about 21,300 MW, of which 97% consists of coal-fired 
power  generation  units.  In  2002,  power  consumption  increased  by  about  15.5%  and 
construction of additional power plants was required. Jiangsu consumes about 100 million tons 
of coal a year and imports about 75% from other provinces. Its extensive dependence on coal

and heating; however, due to the relatively high cost of producing town gas and purchasing 
LPG, most systems are not economical. Also, the provincial government has successfully 
adopted  an  environmental  information  disclosure  program,  which  rates  the  environmental 
performance of industrial firms. Public disclosure of these ratings has been effective in moving 
poorly rated firms to improve their environmental performance. The information has enabled the 
public to take action to monitor the environmental behavior of industrial firms.9 
 
8.  When  construction  of  the  west-east  gas  pipeline  started,  the  Jiangsu  provincial 
government prepared a master plan for introducing and using natural gas in Jiangsu with the 
aim of consuming about 2.3 billion m3 in 2005. This amount is to increase further to about 
5.1 billion m3 after 2010 when the proposed LNG terminal in Jiangsu becomes operational. 
Likewise, the share of natural gas in the primary commercial energy mix is to increase to 3% 
and 6% in 2005 and 2010, respectively. Initially new power plants will be the main consumers of 
natural gas, and four gas-fired power plants with a combined capacity of 3,000 MW are to be 
constructed by 2010. At the same time, the Jiangsu provincial government would also like to 
increase  the  use  of  natural  gas  by  other  consumers,  such  as  industries,  commercial 
establishments, households in urban and rural areas, and vehicles. In particular, the provincial 
government is planning to develop a demonstration project for the efficient use of natural gas 
using advanced technologies that could serve as a model for other areas in the province. 
However, Jiangsu lacks the required policy and regulatory framework and technical expertise for 
developing such a demonstration project and has requested ADB assistance.  
 
9.  The Project is consistent with ADB's strategic objective to help the PRC improve the 
environment. Specifically, the proposed Project will support the PRC in meeting the challenges 
of  urbanization,  including  the  need  to  improve  the  urban  environmental  quality,  as  cities 
continue to grow rapidly with the influx of rural migrants. For this purpose, a proposed loan of 
$100 million has been included in the country program for 2004. The Project can serve as a 
model not only for other areas in the province but also for other energy-deficit and coal-
dependent provinces in the PRC. This should pave the way for further ADB interventions for 
improving the urban environment in the coastal region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The project preparatory TA will assist the provincial government of Jiangsu in developing 
a natural gas demonstration project to maximize the efficient use of natural gas in both urban 
and rural areas of the province and reduce present pollution levels. The main output will be a 
comprehensive feasibility study that will address the proposed optimization of the configuration 
of the high-, medium-, and low-pressure pipelines, which are to be constructed or modified

(existing  ones  for  the  distribution  of  coke  oven  gas  for  commercial  and  residential  use); 
construction  of  additionally  required  modern  gas  infrastructure;  production  and  use  of 
compressed natural gas (CNG) for transportation, and distribution of CNG to rural areas for 
residential consumption; use of natural gas for heating and cooling of buildings; closure of 
polluting coke oven gas production plants; conversion of coal-fired boilers in industries to gas-
fired ones; development of appropriate gas tariffs for urban and rural consumers; investment 
requirements  and  possible  mechanisms  for  private  and  public  sector  participation;  and 
strengthening and capacity building for companies that would operate the natural gas and CNG 
distribution systems. The TA will review the policy and regulatory framework of the natural gas 
sector in Jiangsu and identify relevant issues. The TA will also screen the probable impact of 
the proposed investment on minority ethnic groups. The social and environmental assessments 
are presented in Appendix 2. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented in close consultation with all stakeholders and interested 
parties, including targeted consumers and potential private sector investors. For this purpose, 
two workshops will be held at the midterm stage and the end of TA implementation to explain 
and discuss the consultants’ findings and recommendations of the TA. At the midterm stage, the 
provincial  government,  the  consultants,  and  ADB  will  decide  which  proposed  project 
components  appear  to  be  sufficiently  technically  feasible  for  inclusion  in  a  natural  gas 
demonstration project. During TA implementation, the consultants will work closely with  staff 
from the concerned technical design institutes and the Jiangsu Natural Gas Investment and 
Development Co., Ltd. (JNGIDCL), which was established by the Jiangsu provincial government 
to develop gas infrastructure in Jiangsu Province. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $700,000 equivalent comprising $307,000 as 
foreign exchange and $393,000 equivalent as local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and $193,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding  program.  The  Government  will  finance  the  balance  of  the  local  currency  costs, 
equivalent to $200,000, by providing of counterpart staff, office and communication facilities 
required  for  the  consulting  services,  secretarial  support,  seminars,  and  relevant  studies, 
surveys, and reports. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The provincial government of Jiangsu will be the executing agency for the TA and will 
assign the JNGIDCL as implementing agency to work with the consultants. A working group, 
comprising representatives from the Development Planning Commission of Jiangsu Province; 
JNGIDCL; the Development Planning Committee of Zhenjiang Municipality; Zhenjiang Natural 
Gas Co., Ltd.; and representatives of envisaged major gas consumers, such as industries and 
commercial enterprises, will be established. The working group will regularly meet with the 
consultants to discuss the progress of TA implementation. The provincial government will make 
all relevant studies, reports, and surveys available to the consultants. 
 
14.  The TA will be implemented by an internationally recognized consulting firm or institute 
in association with domestic consultants over a period of about 7 months starting in January 
2004 and is expected to be completed in July 2004. The team of consultants will comprise six 
international  experts  with  experience  in  (i) planning  natural  gas  transmission  and  storage

5 
systems; (ii) natural gas distribution (including CNG applications) and conversion (including 
town gas and LPG distribution systems and coal-fired industrial boilers); (iii) financial and 
institutional  aspects  of  natural  gas  transmission,  distribution,  and  utilization;  (iv)  economic 
analysis of energy projects (including the development of indicators for monitoring the economic 
and environmental impacts of energy projects); (v) environmental impact assessment of energy 
projects; and (vi) analysis of social and poverty reduction aspects of energy projects. The expert 
with experience in planning gas transmission and storage systems or natural gas distribution 
and conversion will act as the team leader. The international consultants will be assisted by six 
domestic experts with experience in (i) natural gas transmission and distribution; (ii) conversion 
of coal-fired boilers to natural gas; (iii) CNG applications; (iv) energy economics; (v) financial 
and institutional analyses, and (vi) environmental impact assessment of energy projects. It is 
estimated that the input of the international consultants will be about 8 person-months—6 in the 
field  and  about  2  in  their  home  office.  The  input  of  the  domestic  consultants  will  be  an 
aggregated 23—12 in the field and 11 in the home office. The outline terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 4.  
 
15.  The consultants will prepare an inception report 2-4 weeks after the consulting services 
begin. Formal tripartite review meetings to discuss the consultants’ midterm and final reports will 
be held within 3 and 5 months, respectively, after commencement of the consulting services. 
ADB will recruit the international and domestic consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants using the quality, and cost-based selection procedure and simplified 
technical  proposals,  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic 
consultants.  ADB  will  finance  the  attendance  of  a  Government  observer  at  the  contract 
negotiations, which will be held at ADB headquarters in Manila. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Jiangsu Urban Environment 
Improvement Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

2.  The  ensuing  Project  will  likely  fall  into  environmental  category  B  and,  if  so,  initial 
environmental examination (IEE) is required to determine whether or not significant environmental 
impacts warrant an environmental impact assessment (EIA). If an EIA is not needed, the IEE is 
regarded as the final environmental assessment report. The terms of reference (TOR) of the 
summary initial environmental examination (SIEE) should include examining the Project's impacts 
on (i) land use, (ii) the environment of local communities, and (iii) cultural sites. The TOR should 
also ensure that appropriate mitigation measures and management procedures are specified and 
their costs estimated and included in the civil works contracts, in conformity with the Asian 
Development Bank's guidelines.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit a team of six international consultants 
and  six  counterpartdomestic  consultants.  The  domestic  consultants  will  work  under  the 
supervision  of  the  international  consultants  and  will  assist  the  international  consultants  in 
accomplishing their tasks. The outline terms of reference for the consultants will include, but will 
not be limited to, the following tasks.1 
 
  A.  Gas Transmission/Distribution Specialists 
 
2.  The specialists will undertake these tasks. 
 
  (i)  Review  the  overall  status  of  the  west-east  gas  pipeline,  gas  infrastructure 
development  plan  of  Jiangsu  Province,  and  the  arrangements  and  expected 
timing for delivery of natural gas to Jiangsu. If required, make recommendations 
for optimizing the configuration of the high-, medium-, low-pressure pipelines, 
and related facilities, which would be constructed or modified (existing ones for 
distributing  coke  oven  gas  for  commercial  and  residential  use)  in  Jiangsu. 
Review site information, including the existing system for regulating gas flow and 
gas distribution in Jiangsu and prepare an energy and gas balance for the 
proposed Project, including modeling to be provided to  the executing agency 
(EA),  the  provincial  government  of  Jiangsu.  Review  the  technical  design 
standards and arrangements for monitoring safety. If required, make adjustments 
in the computer model developed for this purpose. 
  (ii)  Summarize the current status of resources in the energy sector and the gas 
sector for the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Jiangsu Province. Review in 
detail the proposals for production and use of compressed natural gas (CNG), 
transportation and distribution of CNG to rural areas for residential consumption, 
and  use  of  natural  gas  for  heating  and  cooling  buildings.  Identify  required 
institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  building  for  companies  that  would 
operate the natural gas and CNG distribution systems—the Jiangsu Natural Gas 
Investment & Development Co., Ltd., which will act as implementing agency (IA); 
and  related  gas  distribution  companies.  Evaluate  possible  gas  distribution 
arrangements, including franchises for certain areas, and types of distribution 
that would promote private sector participation. 
(iii)  Review  the  project  design  and  if  possible,  present  specific  suggestions  for 
improvement. Recommend pro-poor components that could be included as part 
of the Project and would directly benefit the rural and urban poor in Jiangsu 
Province,  taking  into  account  the  proposals  of  the  EA/IA.  Review  the  EA’s 
proposed program for closure of small, old, polluting boilers and polluting coke 
oven gas production plants and the conversion of coal-fired boilers in industries 
to gas-fired ones in the province. 
(iv)  Review  the  project  cost  estimates—including  the  local  and  foreign  cost 
components and physical and price contingencies—and present them in ADB 
format.  Review  the  EA’s  proposed  contract  packaging  and  suggest 
improvements, taking into account efficiency in procurement and the estimated 
base cost for each package. Determine the financing requirements of the Project 
in terms of both local cost and foreign exchange requirements and identify

options for cofinancing including economical cofinancing under ADB’s guarantee 
operations. 
(v)  Following completion of detailed engineering of the project components to be 
financed by ADB, prepare, in consultation with the EA and ADB, outline bidding 
documents that can be used for the procurement and supply of goods required 
for constructing gas infrastructure. Prepare the project implementation schedule; 
project  the  Project’s  probable  critical  path  and  the  timing  for  each  activity; 
prepare a project procurement schedule, giving the key milestone dates. Assess 
the likely technical risks facing various aspects of the Project and carry out 
sensitivity analysis to check Project viability under these risks. Prepare terms of 
reference (TOR), and person-month estimates for consulting services to assist 
the EA with subsequent project implementation and management. 
 
  B.  Financial/Institutional Analyst 
 
3.  The expert will carry out these tasks. 
 
(i)  Review the accounting and financial records of the EA (if needed) and the IA. 
Present the key audited financial statements for the past 5 years in ADB format. 
Review in detail the EA/IA’s financial position for the last 5 years, based on 
international accounting standards. Project the financial position of the EA/IA for 
the next 10 years, stating the assumptions used; present the projected financial 
performance  in  ADB  format.  Evaluate  the  possibility  of  future  private  sector 
participation in the gas subsector. Present the EA/IA’s investment programs for 
the next 10 years. Examine the feasibility of the program from the financial 
standpoint.  Recommend  measures  that  will  improve  the  EA/IA’s  financial 
position; such measures may include, but will not be limited to, better cost 
recovery  mechanisms,  cost  control  measures,  adjustments  to  investment 
programs, and improvements in the performance of affiliated units. 
(ii)  Review the project cost estimates and financing plan. Discuss the methodology 
for  assessing  the  financial  viability  of  the  Project  and  each  of  the  project 
components.  Determine  the  financial  viability  of  the  Project  and  of  its 
components; include a computation of the project financial internal rate of return 
and the weighted average cost of capital as well as a review of the potential cash 
flows  of  the  Project  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines.  Assess  the  likely 
financial  uncertainties  and  risks  associated  with  the  Project,  and  carry  out 
sensitivity analysis to check the viability of the Project and its components under 
these risks and uncertainties. Prepare sales and gas purchase agreements, 
acceptable to ADB. 
(iii)  Undertake a thorough review of the internal controls within the EA/IA to ensure 
that they are consistent with ADB’s  Guidelines on Prevention of Fraud and 
Corruption. Present the recommended organizational structure of the finance 
departments of the EA/IA. In consultation with the EA/IA and the institutional 
experts, propose a capital/ownership structure for the IA and develop a financial 
reporting system that will enable the EA to monitor the financial performance of 
the IA. 
(iv)  Describe the role and responsibilities of the various sector institutions and their 
relationships and the relationship among the EA, the IA, and the provincial and 
local governments; present the delegation of authority in key areas such as 
corporate governance, long-term planning, investment approval, appointment of 
key personnel, setting performance targets, monitoring performance, and a chart

14  Appendix 4 
showing the gas sector institutions and their relationships. Present the number of 
staff and staffing pattern in the EA/IA; categorize the staff and describe their 
available  skills;  describe  the  training  being  given  and  the  available  training 
facilities; and present recommendations for improving staff recruitment, training, 
and training facilities. Describe the management process in the EA/IA, including 
delegation of authority for investment approval, procurement, long-term plans, 
annual budgets, staff recruitment, staff benefits, and the role of the various 
departments and coordination among them. 
(v)  Present the EA/IA’s corporate objectives and goals. Assess how gas sector 
reforms can facilitate these corporate long-term goals and objectives. Assess 
how the enterprise reforms can be achieved within the framework of corporate 
long-term  goals  and  objectives;  recommend  measures  for  institutional 
strengthening,  including  organization  structure,  corporate  governance, 
operational  efficiency,  delegation  of  power,  and  greater  commercialization. 
Recommend  measures  for  strengthening  the  organizational  aspects  of 
implementation arrangements for the Project, including the role of the EA/IA in 
project implementation. Assess the management capabilities of the EA/IA to 
manage the Project. Identify key issues and evaluate the prospects for private 
sector participation in the IA. 
(vi)  Describe the institutional arrangements for transfer and delivery of gas under the 
Project; recommend commercial arrangements for efficient utilization and better 
cost recovery; and prepare a draft agreement. Identify areas where the EA/IA 
require assistance for institutional strengthening, including corporate governance 
and enterprise reforms, and prepare the TOR. Identify suitable training programs 
for staff of the EA/IA. 
 
  C.  Economic Analyst 
 
4.  The economic analyst will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  Provide general macro and sector information, including energy production and 
consumption by sector, energy efficiency, and gas production and consumption 
by sector for the PRC and Jiangsu Province. Make an independent assessment 
of the short-term (3 years) and long-term (system planning period) demand 
forecasts that take into account historical trends, structural changes, efficiency 
improvement,  energy  prices,  gross  domestic  product  growth,  investment 
distribution and growth, and other important factors affecting energy and gas 
demand in Jiangsu Province. Discuss in detail the assumptions and methodology 
used in forecasting demand. 
(ii)  Compare, in terms of economic costs and benefits, the proposed use of natural 
gas and its alternative use as household fuel in the project areas. Analyze the 
economic parameters. Identify the quantitative and qualitative benefits of the 
Project and each component. Carry out economic analysis based on ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects, specifically including (a) gas 
demand  analysis,  (b)  least-cost  and  equalizing  discount  rate  analysis, 
(c) economic  viability  analysis,  and  (d)  risk  analysis.  Discuss  alternative 
methodologies for carrying out the economic analysis. 
(iii)  Describe how the tariffs of the Project will be determined. Incorporate into the 
economic analysis economic quantification of the Project’s environmental impact 
following ADB’s  Environmental Guidelines for Selected Industrial and Power 
Development  Projects,  Environmental  Assessment  Requirements  and

Appendix 4  15 
Environmental Review Procedures, and Economic Valuation of Environmental 
Impacts: A Workbook, 1996. Clearly discuss and present the assumptions and 
methodology. 
(iv)  Discuss the assumptions and the economic parameters used in the economic 
analysis, including the assumed consumers’ willingness to pay and resource cost 
savings in relation to alternative options; compare the shadow prices with those 
in ADB’s or the World Bank’s projects, and discuss the source and justification 
for the shadow prices. Identify and analyze likely economic  uncertainties that 
could affect the Project's viability, and carry out a detailed risk analysis. 
(v)  Assess  the  possibilities  for  private  sector  participation  in  gas  transmission, 
distribution,  and  utilization.  Recommend  effective  policy  dialogue  to  promote 
private sector participation in the gas subsector and help create a conducive 
environment. 
 
D.  Environmental Expert 
 
5.  The expert will carry out these tasks. 
 
(i)  Summarize the current status of environmental pollution in the PRC and Jiangsu 
Province. Help the EA improve the environmental impact assessment (EIA) for 
the Project following ADB’s Environmental Guidelines for Selected Industrial and 
Power Development Projects and Environmental Assessment Requirements and 
Environmental Review Procedures to ensure that the EIA is comprehensive and 
complies with ADB’s requirements, including the format for presentation. Give the 
EA specific and detailed recommendations for revisions and/or additional studies, 
if  needed,  to  make  the  EIA  conform  to  ADB’s  requirements.  Quantify  the 
environmental impact and benefits resulting from the EA’s proposed program for 
closure of small, old boilers in Jiangsu, and suggest a scheme for environmental 
monitoring while decommissioning the plants. 
(ii)  Prepare a summary EIA following  ADB’s  format  prescribed  in Environmental 
Assessment Requirements and Environmental Review Procedures. Assess other 
options for gas production/distribution and meeting the energy demand; compare 
their  environmental  and  social  sustainability.  Review  the  environmental 
management  capabilities  of  the  EA  and  the  local  environmental  protection 
bureaus and, if appropriate, recommend institutional strengthening measures. 
Review the safety record of underground coal mines in Jiangsu Province and the 
impact of improving occupational safety in such coal mines under the Project. 
(iii)  In preparing the environmental analysis, focus on the risk analysis for the high-
and medium-pressure pipelines and any storage facilities for the natural gas 
pipelines. For the closure of polluting coke oven gas plants, the consultant needs 
to focus on land rehabilitation and remediation procedures. Monitoring potential 
groundwater contamination, air contamination, built-up understructures especially 
for schools, and residential areas has to be considered.  
 
E.  Poverty /Social Analyst 
 
6.  The analyst will perform these tasks. 
 
(i)  Conduct a site visit to verify the initial poverty and social assessment. Collect 
available reports and published statistics that are relevant to the Project. Identify 
the  stakeholders  of  the  proposed  Project;  examine  their  existing  rights  and

16  Appendix 4 
possible risks from the Project. Assist the EA in building public acceptance of the 
Project. 
(ii)  Organize  and  conduct  surveys  in  the  project  area  and  consult  with  the 
government and nongovernment organizations to supplement secondary data. 
Prepare a poverty profile of the project area. Indicate the poverty incidence, the 
current  situation,  and  the  trend;  include  characteristics  of  poverty  and  the 
perceptions of people, gathered through surveys or existing poverty assessments 
of the project area. Assess the pro-poor impacts of the Project, taking into 
account linkage effects. Provide details of the potential impacts on the economy 
in the project area, particularly on the poor. Identify ways to make the Project 
pro-poor; specify indicators for measuring the pro-poor impacts; design a time-
bound  plan  for  monitoring;  and  outline  the  plan  and  resources  required  to 
implement the monitoring plan. 
(iii)  Estimate the number of poor people who will benefit from the Project. Estimate 
the proportion of poor who will benefit from government expenditure. Where 
there is a net cost to the Government, estimate the proportion of marginal tax 
revenue derived from the poor. For net benefits to the economy, estimate the 
proportion  directly  benefiting  the  poor.  Calculate  the  poverty  impact  ratio. 
Conduct risk analysis for key variables and assumptions used in calculating the 
ratio, and explain the implications. Provide a statement of the project features 
relating to poverty reduction. 
(iv)  Assess social and gender considerations as part of the project design. Prepare a 
social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Incorporation of Social 
Dimensions in ADB Operations. Determine the likely social and gender effects, 
such as any joblessness resulting from closure of old boilers in Jiangsu Province. 
Identify  any  mitigation  measures  or  complementary  activity  that  would  help 
reduce poverty in the project area. Assess whether there will be adverse or 
disproportionate effects on ethnic minority nationalities. If impacts are significant, 
prepare an ethnic minority development plan. Investigate whether the Project will 
require  land  requisition  and  whether  any  housing,  farmland,  or  commercial 
property  will  be  affected.  In  such  cases,  prepare  a  resettlement  plan  in 
accordance with  ADB's Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and  Handbook on 
Resettlement. Design appropriate socioeconomic monitoring and management 
plans to be implemented by the EA. Specify social analysis, recommendations on 
changes  in  design  to  incorporate  social  dimensions,  and  socioeconomic 
monitoring plans as separate outputs. 
(v)  Identify relevant (a) indicators, (b) methodology, (c) plan and timing, (d) location, 
and (e) human resource requirements to undertake an analysis of poverty impact 
in the area where the Project is expected to have an impact. Incorporate these 
indicators  should  be  incorporated  into  the  project  performance  monitoring 
system. 
 
  F.  Domestic Project Monitoring/Data Analysts 
 
7.  The domestic experts will (i) review the project-related documents to determine a set of 
monitorable indicators for economic growth, energy efficiency, gas reduction and environmental 
improvement; (ii) develop a project framework that outlines the goal, purposes,  outputs, and 
inputs or activities with links to the set of monitorable indicators; (iii) assess availability of data 
for the monitorable indicators; (iv) determine a feedback and reporting mechanism for effective 
project implementation; and (v) prepare a framework for initial start-up activities, including a 
baseline survey to be monitored with the follow-up surveys.
